conclusion: Analyze the dynamics of the dipole in the magnetic field to determine the minimum angular velocity required for the dipole to reverse its orientation.
The dipole consists of two charges, +q and -q, connected by a rigid rod of length d.
The magnetic field B is uniform and perpendicular to the XY-plane.
The Lorentz force on each charge due to the magnetic field is given by F = q (v × B).
The dipole rotates about its center of mass, so the velocity of each charge is tangential to the circular motion.
For the charge +q, the velocity is v+ = ω (d/2) ŷ, and for the charge -q, the velocity is v- = -ω (d/2) ŷ.
The magnetic forces on the charges are F+ = q (v+ × B) and F- = q (v- × B).
Since B is perpendicular to the XY-plane (B = B ẑ), the forces are F+ = q ω (d/2) x̂ and F- = -q ω (d/2) x̂.
The forces F+ and F- create a torque about the center of mass of the dipole.
The torque τ is given by τ = r+ × F+ + r- × F-, where r+ and r- are the position vectors of the charges relative to the center of mass.
The position vectors are r+ = (d/2) x̂ and r- = -(d/2) x̂.
The torque contributions are r+ × F+ = (d/2) x̂ × q ω (d/2) x̂ = 0 and r- × F- = -(d/2) x̂ × -q ω (d/2) x̂ = 0.
